body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When developing new features for mermaid itself, it can be hard to review them easily, as there is no easy way to just play around with Mermaid diagrams in the browser. This discussion came up for the [C4 integration](https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/pull/3151#issuecomment-1174676087).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Ideally, each PR creates a custom deployment of the [Mermaid Live Editor](https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid-live-editor), using the PRs version of Mermaid. This could be achieved with a service like Netlify that is already used to deploy the production version of the Mermaid Live Editor.

The biggest challenge is to get the correct mermaid version to be used by the Live Editor. In the current form, the Live Editor uses the npm repository to install mermaid itself.
One solution to this problem could be to move the project into a monorepo, and then to use the local git version of Mermaid instead of the npm version. This could be facilitated with a monorepo management tool like [rush](https://rushjs.io/) or [turborepo](https://turborepo.org/).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
The simplest alternative to a live editor would be running mermaid PRs locally with help of the e2e setup, but this would be significantly more work for a reviewer compared to just clicking a link in the PR.

As an alternative to using a monorepo, we could change the Live Editor to load mermaid asynchronously with an option to select the source, and publish a mermaid version for each PR. This would be significantly more work than moving the projects to a monorepo.

Instead of Netlify, we could also use other services like e.g. Amplify, but since the editor already uses Netlify, this might be additional work without additional benefits.

**Additional context**
I'm happy to help around implementation. I've already moved open source projects to monorepos and have experience specifically with rush.

Hi all!

#### 1. feature-name
open source business vision

#### 2. feature-description
I would like to contribute to the community through 13 ideas on how to make the mermaid open source project more profitable, when I say profitable, I mean economically viable. Most open source projects work on the subscription model, donation model (monthly/yearly) or premium service model (open core: part open source, part closed source - which is different from the freepremium model, there are people that confuse the freepremium model with the opencore model. I'll say briefly, the freepremium model doesn't exist part of open source and part of closed source. What exists is a proprietary code software with a free part and a paid part, when I say it is free - I don't mean freedom, I mean financially, it's free because you don't pay.  The idea is to give the user a taste of how the software is, so if the user is interested, he (user) pays for the software he wants to use. opencore business model, part of the code is open, that is, the user does not pay for the software and can still see its source code. If he wants to support the project, he can pay a monthly/annual subscription service. This is the main difference between opencore and freepremium.)

#### 2.1. Open source business vision
1. Direct sale of diagram templates in mermaid: *The idea is that it would be a single sale per person, in which case it would be a service to be done and paid for. The person can make the diagram template available to someone else for free or not.*
3. Consultancy on creating diagram templates in mermaid: *Anyone who is a developer or someone who has knowledge of the mermaid language can create unique diagram models for individuals and companies. These people can make these unique diagram templates available to other people or companies if they express an interest in doing so for free or not.*
4. Indirect sale of diagram models in mermaid: *the idea would be something monthly from developers to users for free or not*
5. Storage of diagram templates in mermaid: *Companies interested in the mermaid community may have the mermaid diagram template storage service - companies may charge a monthly or annual fee to provide access to or storage of mermaid diagram templates for free or not.*
6. Monthly or annual donation from people to the mermaid community: *This allows for an interest in individuals or corporations to support the mermaid project. Which can be good to hire more developers and provide more premium services in order to make mermaid openly available.* - ***This is an example of what I call a collective investment fund or crowdfunding.***
7. Extensibility is a key point, as an open source project we can provide other plugins and integrations with mermaid. - *"Get Paid To Build Open Source Extensions for Existing Products"*
8. Sponsorship: *Is different from donation, generally those who are part of the sponsorship can be companies or individuals. But most of the cases are usually companies. There can be sponsorship with monthly/annual donation or without donation - there are cases where the donation would be servers, maintenance and equipment.*
9. Paid Feature Requests
10. Software as a Service
11. Paid Support or Courses: *Red Hat‚Äôs model of open source software financed by paid support contracts and on-premise configuration takes more human hours, but it allows them to improve the user experience dramatically. When companies look at the cost to troubleshoot open source software, it‚Äôs usually a better deal to sign up with the people who made the software rather than learn it themselves.*
12. Paid certification: *If software is popular enough, companies can offer certification opportunities for specialists who want to validate their knowledge and skills. Getting certified, as a developer, is quite useful for a number of reasons. First, it‚Äôs a great opportunity to differentiate yourself among other specialists with the same skills. Second, developers realize the importance of networking with mentors and groupmates. Finally, a developer‚Äôs certification leads lends them additional professional credibility and even promotions, and can boost a company‚Äôs image.*
13. Advertising tech events or mermaid talks: There are things like ruby-conf, python-conf which are paid community talks for people or companies. This is usually done with sponsorship or with a monthly/annual donation from the community itself.
14. Own hosting, self-hosting: The company or person can use mermaid in their own hosting or in the hosting of the mermaid community.

#### 2.2 Why? *notes*
1. In indirect or direct selling, the community can earn money through sales commission, which is a fee you receive for the sale. This cash receipt rate per sale can be somewhere around 15% or 10% - usually the sales rate around 15% or 10% is done on things like Workana, Freelancer.com etc. It's a sales rate that I put here as a reference.
2. It might be of interest to the mermaid community if there is collective interest in providing a consulting platform for creating mermaid diagram models - this allows business analysts like me to make their services available to the community and thus sell their service - with this, I earn money for the work service I do, which would be the consultancy for creating mermaid diagram models, as well as the exclusive sale of diagram models, either indirectly or directly. The main advantage of this type of business here would be the return of the fee charged for the service provided by consultants to individuals/legal entities.
3. It's a way to make money like Wordpress.

I suppose I have two feature requests regarding this issue:

2) Add a vertical line at the specified date. Along with feature 1), this would allow a nice way to mark and specify dates of starts and ends of events.

I'm thinking something like this:

Generated with something like this:

```
gantt
    title Leave Plan

    axisFormat %b-%d
    section Time off
    Sabbatical start -- 2022-10-03       :milestone, birth, 2022-10-03, 0d

**Describe the bug**
There's no list of which Font Awesome icons are supported. So Mermaid does not appear to display certain icons in [current documentation](https://fontawesome.com/v6/icons) (as of today's date, 18,000+ icons). 

Mermaid actually supports an [older version of FA with roughly 675 icons](https://fontawesome.com/v4/icons/). To complicate the issue, FA appears to have deprecated its font codes in favor of a simpler syntax, e.g. getting rid of `fa-` prefixes. To further complicate the issue, Mermaid may be supporting an earlier release of version 4 since even some of those don't display.

The version of FA (version 4?) supported by Mermaid should be documented to reduce confusion and allow users to have a baseline on what they can use in their charts. 

**Expected behavior**
Documentation where the version of Font Awesome supported should be listed is currently at https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/flowchart?id=basic-support-for-fontawesome .

**Additional context**
There appears to be a lot of confusion about FA support. This documentation update may help clear up any questions and potentially reduce the number of tickets coming in about FA.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I am trying to use property strings on class diagrams.

In standard UML, operations (_methods_) have the following syntax:

```
[visibility] name [(parameter-list)] [: return-type] [{property-string}]
```

However, property strings (the last element) are not currently supported by Mermaid.

For instance, the following code is marked as syntactically incorrect:

```mermaid
classDiagram
class MyClass{
      +x(parameter) A
      +y() B {property}
    }
```

**Describe the solution you'd like**
It would be great if Mermaid added support for these property strings.

It doesn't need to do it using curly brackets, if that inserts ambiguity in the syntax of the language. For example, using `[square brackets]` seems like a viable option to me.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
`"quotation marks"` could also work for the implementation of property strings. I think that might be more intuitive.

Other option would be to use a similar approach to [labels on relationships](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/classDiagram?id=defining-relationship).

All in all, there's different possibilities for the implementation, and no clear better choice.

**Additional context**
The following would an example of how to render a property string:
![example-class](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/20495460/176400283-1aacaace-fade-432b-be6e-1655aa996165.png)

For further context, you can read more about property strings on any UML reference textbook.

A good one is: _The Unified Modeling Language User Guide_; G. Booch, J. Rumbaugh, I.Jacobson; Addison-Wesley; First Edition. (Chapter 9, "operations").
Another good one is: _UML Distilled_; M. Fowler; Addison-Wesley; Third Edition. (chapter 3, page 44).

body:
**Describe the bug**

According to #1228 and #1574, dashes / hyphens (-) should be supported in sequence diagrams. And indeed, if actors are only implicitly defined, they can be used when specifying relationships. 

However, if actors are explicitly defined using `participant` tags (as [described in the docs](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/sequenceDiagram?id=sequencenumbers)), the diagram fails to render. If escape characters are used, duplicate actors are created.

As software components often contain dashes in their names, it would be helpful to be able to represent those as accurately as possible.

**To Reproduce**

Attempt to render any of the following diagrams:

```
sequenceDiagram
    participant jelly-bean
    participant chocolate-chip

    jelly-bean->chocolate-chip: applies heat
    chocolate-chip->jelly-bean: reports melting condition
```

```
sequenceDiagram
    participant jelly#45;bean
    participant chocolate#45;chip

    jelly-bean->chocolate-chip: applies heat
    chocolate-chip->jelly-bean: reports melting condition
```

```
sequenceDiagram
    participant jelly#45;bean
    participant chocolate#45;chip

    jelly#45bean->chocolate#45chip: applies heat
    chocolate#45chip->jelly#45bean: reports melting condition
```


**Expected behavior**

That the above samples render as below:

<!-- This diagram does not explicitly define actors as participants, which is why it works, but once this issue is solved those should be able to be defined explicitly with participant tags. -->
```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    jelly-bean->>chocolate-chip: applies heat
    chocolate-chip->>jelly-bean: reports melting condition
```

The expected behavior would be that there would be a way to include dashes in actor names, both when declaring participants, and describing messages.

The most convenient way to allow this would be to support directly typing dashes in both `participant` and message descriptions, or allow quotation marks to describe literal names in both, escaping the interpretation of any special characters. 

**Additional context**

#1228
#1574

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

As an analyst I want to model [critical region (with options) blocks](https://stackoverflow.com/a/29804503) and [break blocks](https://stackoverflow.com/a/33010693) within sequence diagrams to have a more fine grained semantic shown to my diagram consumers.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

For a "critical region" and "option" blocks I'd like to define the following within my sequence diagram to indicate a block that has to be executed no matter what, with multiple "option" blocks to cover any special conditions that occurred during the "critical region" block:
```
sequenceDiagram
    critical Establish a connection to the DB
        Service-->DB: connect
    option Network timeout
        Service-->Service: Log error
    option Credentials rejected
        Service-->Service: Log different error
    end
```
For a "break" block, indicating a thrown exception (and thereby an exit of the sequence) as follows:
```
sequenceDiagram
    Consumer-->API: Book something
    API-->BookingService: Start booking process
    break when the booking process fails
        API-->Consumer: show failure
    end
    API-->BillingService: Start billing process
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

For "Critical Region": Nope, there's no design element that would cover that very semantic within sequence diagrams.
For "Break": Well, that could probably be handled with an "alt" or "opt" block. But semantically the execution doesn't stop after an "alt" or "opt" block as it is indicated with a "break" block.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

When developing a new diagram type for mermaid it is a huge change to the complete mermaid code. Currently there is the diagram code in the diagrams folder itself, and other necessary changes: defaultConfig.js, Diagram.js, mermaidAPI.js, styles.js, utils.js and several locations in the files contained in the themes folder (did I miss something?).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The ideal solution - imho - would be that the mermaid project is split up into:
- mermaid API package
- diagram packages (one dedicated package for each mermaid diagram type - could also be bundling more diagram types)
  - which use the mermaid API package to register their styles, theme-extensions, default-configs, logic-functions, ...
- mermaid logic package
  - which also uses the mermaid API package to utilise the previously registered diagrams

In the end the base code of mermaid should be free of any diagram information, can focus on orchestration and must only consume the mermaid API - no hard-coded imports of diagrams and neither should the diagram packages import anything from the mermaid logic package.

Then an using app could "simply" import the mermaid logic package and the supported diagrams (or a diagram-bundle-package).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

The currently available alternative is to add new diagram types and have a huge junk of the mermaid code base also changed.

**Additional context**

- It would also be nice to have the monaco-mermaid declarations integrated into a diagram package, so the diagram package "out-of-the-box" provides auto-completion for apps using the monaco-editor (like the mermaid-live-editor). Tho, that can be a separate task and should be proposed to the monaco-mermaid maintainers/contributors.
- Such a mechanism can be implemented along side the current diagrams (to not break existing apps which already have mermaid integrated). At the latest when the project is split into multiple components the project probably should be renamed to mermaid2 (or have a major version change) to indicate incompatibility to the previous integration.
- Implementing this strategy would also enable/resolve https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/issues/2459 in the future.

**Implementation proposal**

1) try to get diagram specifics within the diagrams folder without splitting the project (the backward compatible change for currently integrating apps)
    1) identify all necessary information to put into an appropriate "DiagramAPI" object
       1. extended Theme attributes
       2. styles and diagram-scss/css
       3. default-config
       4. diagram type/name
       5. diagram parser
       6. diagram renderer
       7. ...
    2) extend the current logic to use that DiagramAPI object if no default diagram was identified (such in utils.js:detectType, the switch-case in mermaidAPI.js:render and Diagram.js:Diagram.constructor, ...)
    3) try to implement the sequence-diagram with that approach (make it a sequenceDiagram-v2 or so) as a PoC
    4) ... (did I forget something?)
    5) migrate existing diagram types to that approach and consequently cleanup the orchestrating code
2) split the project 
  
---

@financelurker thats a good idea. I think that we are reaching a point where the base package of mermaid needs to be split up. If you don't care about gantt charts why include and load them? I have been thinking about a lazy loading. This could be another way or even better a part of that setup.

There are some refactoring activities that need to happen first though. The code that initially handled two diagrams is not as clean when handling 10+ diagrams after"organic growth". We need to define what a diagram is so that mermaid can treat them all diagrams in the same way with a basic interface. This is high up on my prioritisation list and diagram organisation is a part of that.

_Originally posted by @knsv in https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/issues/2456#issuecomment-1106034124_

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I really like the `classDiagram` Feature. We use it in university for our students to quickly and easily make some UML class diagrams for their projects. The only problem is that we can't use the official UML syntax for attributes like this: `-name: String` in conjunction with the **abstract** `*` and **static** `$` flags. This works for an attribute that is build like this: `-String name` but not for `-name: String`.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I think a useful tool like this should support the official UML attribute syntax.
A possible syntax could look like this `-name1: String*` or maybe this `-name1*: String`

**Additional context**
Here is an example of the current behavior of mermaid:

```
classDiagram
    class Example {
        -name1: String*
        -name2: String$
        -name1*: String
        -name2$: String
        -String name1*
        -String name2$
    }
```
```mermaid
classDiagram
    class Example {
        -name: String*
        -name: String$
        -name*: String
        -name$: String
        -String name*
        -String name$
    }
```

## The issue

In a lot of cases, sequence diagrams would be beneficial for making documentation around systems more clear, in which case, the 'Actors' or 'Participants' would be presented as components of an application, system, module or even network. Showing the interaction between these various components.

The current documentation around sequence diagrams builds upon the premise of 'Actors' and 'Participants' by using examples where they are represented as people and the interactions are simple communications. 

This fails to provide a clear and deeper technical understanding to the reader as to the true use-cases of these diagrams.

## The Question

I'd like to add more technical diagrams to the [sequenceDiagram.md](https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/blob/develop/docs/sequenceDiagram.md) page that give examples more orientated towards software, such as inner workings of classes in OOP, or instance communication in a cloud network.

Are there be any suggestions, or objections, to this before I submit work on this?

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, there is no way to typeset mathematical equations in diagrams created with Mermaid.

**Describe the solution you'd like**.
To remedy this, I propose implementing Katex into Mermaid 

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
MathJax is another similar library for typesetting mathematical equations and provides direct SVG support, but it is slower in creating the desired output. This could cause a longer delay when updating Mermaid diagrams after making modifications.

**Additional context**
* This issue is similar to the closed issue #1387
* I've already started on a rudimentary implementation for flowcharts to assess the difficulty and time needed to implement this. Currently, it involves adding an additional step after processing the regex for FontAwesomeIcons, which searches for a LaTeX equation surrounded by a delimiter and converts it to stringified HTML. I'd like to hear the core maintainers thoughts before I proceed further with my implementation.

**Describe the bug**

When a class member declaration is used without a class declaration, nothing is drawn in Mermaid.

For example, the following does not emit anything:

```
classDiagram
  Monkey: +name string 1
```

A separate class declarations is required, even though this class declaration does not include any information that is not already in the class member declaration.  The following emits the class + member as expected:

```
classDiagram
  class Monkey
  Monkey: +name string 1
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Copy/paste the first snippet into a Mermaid editor and observe that nothing is drawn and no error or warning is emitted.
2. Copy/paste the second snippet into a Mermaid editor and observe that the class and method are drawn.

**Expected behavior**
- I expect the class member declaration to be sufficient to result in a visualization showing the class and method,
- Or I expect an error or warning, indicating that a class method declaration without a corresponding class declaration will not be drawn by Mermaid.

body:
I think that MermaidJS is a great idea, a language to write diagrams, but this repository needs some organizing because I have seen dead documentation and inconsistent code-style in many places.

## Ideas

These are some ideas that I came up with to make `mermaid` a better project.

- [ ] Enforce Code styling
  I have seen the code having inconsistent code style in many places
  - [x] Add a GitHub Action
  - [x] Add a `lint:fix` script (#2471)
  - [x] Lint all files
	  - Note that for the HTML files, the HTML will have to be escaped to prevent parsing errors and messed up the formatting
	  - [x] Use `eslint-plugin-markdown` (#2530)
	  - [x] Use `eslint-plugin-html` (#2531)
	  - [x] Use [`prettier`](https://prettier.io/) on all files (not only `src/**/*.js`)
	    - Many files of many types have inconsistent `prettier` code-style
	    - [x] Use [`prettier-plugin-jsdoc`](https://www.npmjs.com/package/prettier-plugin-jsdoc) (#2471)
  - [x] Add a commit hook using Husky (#1878) (#2522)
  - [ ] Enforce `.editorconfig` is followed using linters
  - [ ] Use [`stylelint`](https://stylelint.io/)
  - [x] Use `eslint-plugin-jsdoc` https://npmjs.com/package/eslint-plugin-jsdoc (#2471)
    - When implementing this remember to turn off conflicting rules with `prettier-plugin-jsdoc`
- [ ] Documentation
	- [x] Synchronize `README` and `docs/README` (see https://github.com/Yash-Singh1/eslint-plugin-userscripts/blob/main/.github/workflows/readme-in-sync.yml)
	- [x] Synchronize `CHANGELOG` and `docs/CHANGELOG`
	- [x] Merge flowchart docs in `  
diagrams-and-syntax-and-examples` and at root of docs and move all diagram documentation to `  
diagrams-and-syntax-and-examples`
  - [x] Remove `theme_themed.css`
  - [x] Remove redundant example and code (see https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/pull/2449#issue-770022456) (#2449)
  - [x] Group images in `landing` inside a new `img` folder
  - [x] Use [`markdownlint`](https://github.com/DavidAnson/markdownlint) so the documentation is more maintainable
  - [x] Grammar and casing in multiple files
  - [ ] Finish up `n00b-advanced.md`
  - [ ] Reference and update the `upgrading.md` and `breakingChanges.md`
  - [ ] Search for and remove dead documentation and images
  - [ ] Keep syntax and docs in sync (there are many parsing features that are in the code but not in the docs, e.g. #2340, #2275)
	  - Maybe make it necessary to document changes to syntax
 - [ ] Metadata
	 - [x] Update descriptions in `package.json`
	 - [x] Actually install defined Husky Hooks  (#2522)
	 - [ ] Move `todo.md` somewhere else
		 - I understand it might be useful for personal notes, but putting that in GitHub projects, or making it more formal as a `ROADMAP.md` would be better
	- [x] Mark `dist/*`  as `linguist-generated`
	- [x] Have more specific issue templates (#2739)
		- [x] Diagram Proposals
		- [x] Syntax Proposals
		- [x] Theme Proposals
	- [x] Don't lock/unlock issues (#967) (#2503)
	    - This prevents users from being able to give their ideas against why the issues are closed because there are times when the issue is closed and then another idea is brought up.
	- [ ] Add some sort of deploy bot to allow preview of documentation on PRs (maybe Netlify because that is what we use in `mermaid-live-editor`)
	- [ ] Standardize commit message with https://www.conventionalcommits.org/en/v1.0.0/ (#2529)
- [x] Bulid
	- [x] Don't push `dist` to GitHub
	- [x] Group `webpack` files
- [ ] Source
    - [x] Add JSDOC to helper functions to help contributors and add IntelliSense (#2464)
    - [ ] Switch from Annex B `escape` and `unescape` to something else

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

It is possible to style nodes in `graph` diagrams with a `style` declaration.  The same feature is not available for `classDiagram` diagrams.

Adding support for the `style` keyword will allow non-technical users to configure the color of nodes and other styling properties.  Current solutions rely on changing the CSS context, but this requires deep access to the web page in which the Mermaid diagram is integrated.  Regular users cannot make such changes when they are working within a pre-configured web service.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Support for the `style` keyword in `classDiagram` diagrams.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

The alternative is that a separate CSS context is created where the styling is applied.  But such CSS contexts cannot be integrated in most existing Markdown environments.  They require changes to the overall web page.  Most users of existing services do not have the ability to change this.

**Additional context**

The following works and makes the node yellow:

```mermaid
graph
  style Monkey fill: yellow
```

The following does not work and does not generate a diagram:

```mermaid
classDiagram
  style Monkey fill: yellow

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I have been looking into several issues related to propagating the syntax errors from mermaid to other clients, e.g. mermaid-cli. By inspecting the code of mermaid.js (https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/blob/d0408832868b45f70756f9d9ebcd6271eab20218/src/mermaid.js#L122), I can see that all errors are caught on the mermaid level and never propagated to the clients. **Describe the solution you'd like**
Make another function called init(), rename existing one to initThrowsErrors(). The new init() calls initThrowsErrors() and try-catch lives in init(). Then clients can choose either to call init() or initThrowsErrors()

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Remove try-catch in the current implementation of init()
Reimplement parts of the init() in mermaid-cli

## Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

In class diagrams, it's not possible to use generic extension methods (e.g. for c#).

C#, notice the `<T>` and `this`:
````cs
public int Foo<T>(this T value, int maximum, string message) { /* ... */}
````

Mermaid, notice the `~T~` and `this`:
````
classDiagram
  class Foo {
    +Foo~T~(this T, int, string)$ int
  }
````

It incorrectly renders as `this T`. A live sample [is here](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/edit/#).

## Describe the solution you'd like
To be able to specify the generic `~T~` and the `this` for the same method signature.

## Describe alternatives you've considered
A dirty workaround:
````
classDiagram
  class Foo {
    +Foo_T(this T, int, string)$ int
  }
````

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I work at a software company and we are investigating using mermaid for documentation of our scenario flows.  To do this we would use the sequence diagrams and create an actor for each component of a scenario.  Most actors are web services.  These web services each have their own repos, their own telemetry dashboards, their own set of on-call engineers, their own documentation, their own troubleshooting guide, etc.  

We plan to use the scenario sequence diagrams for multiple purposes, however a key purpose will be for troubleshooting live site incidents.  During a live site incident, it would be super awesome to be able to drill down from the scenario flow into the current health of any of the production services participating in that scenario.   Also, to easily find the on-call engineers for any service, or find the trouble shooting guide for any service.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
An engineer viewing the sequence diagram could hover their mouse over the actor shape causing a dropdown menu to popup containing hyperlinks to user-defined web sites associated with that actor.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Looked into using Visio.  It has this capability already, however, it is more heavyweight and harder to work with compared to mermaid.

**Additional context**
I have already built a proof-of-concept for this feature in the mermaid codebase.

Following on from a great PR https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/pull/1599 by @jgreywolf and the original issue reported https://github.com/mermaid-js/mermaid/issues/1181, I've been trying to apply custom css to different elements within a class diagrams and seem to have come across a few issues I thought it was worth reporting. The issues I've listed below are in the order I found them The documentation states that something like the below should apply the relevant CSS to an element, but I'm seeing a syntax error ```
classDiagram class test1 cssClass "test1" customCss;
``` This seems to be due to a typo in the documentation which states a semi-colon is needed when assigning the CSS `cssClass "nodeId1" cssClass;` Removing the semi-colon fixes this (I spotted an example in the tests without a semi colon) `cssClass "nodeId1" cssClass` After this it worked, well, kind of... I was able to apply custom CSS, but only to CSS properties that aren't already being used, so existing properties weren't being overridden To get round this I added `!important` to the properties I want to override, but this obviously isn't ideal. The class name is being correctly assigned to the node, but because the default styles are being assigned via a `
classDiagram class test1 cssClass "test1" customCss
``` I'm not sure if this issue would be picked up in the tests, I could be wrong but from what I can see the tests check to see if a SVG is generated, not whether they contain the correct colours? - Device: Macbook Pro - OS: macOS Big Sur 11.4 - Browser Chrome - Version 91.0.4472.114 (Official Build) (x86_64) I'm no js expert, but thought I'd post this in the hope someone might pick it up, or maybe this will help someone work around a problem instead of spending a couple of hours figuring out why their diagrams aren't working as expected

**Describe the bug**
The [mermaid class documentation](https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid/#/classDiagram?id=return-type) indicates that you can specify the return type by placing a space before the final type. The documentation uses the example `+deposit(amount) bool`. In JavaScript method names can be computed. A common example is using a Symbol for the method name. When a computed method name is used, `+[Symbol.hasInstance](type)$ boolean` the return type will not be displayed in the class diagram.

BTW, it would be nice to have a way to specify parameter types differently. For example, using TypeScript notation `+[Symbol.hasInstance](type : any)$ boolean` rather than forcing the datatype to be before the parameter name... wouldn't mind specifying it before so long as it came out in the diagram how it's specified in the programming language you are using.

**To Reproduce**
```text
classDiagram
class any
any : +constructor()$ any
any : +[Symbol.hasInstance](type)$ boolean

body:
There are two implementations of state diagrams, the initial one and one using the the mermaid specific dagre-wrapper renderer. The dragre-wrapper version has been available for a long time by starting the diagram with `stateDiagram-v2` and this render make a number of new features possible for state diagrams like for instance:

* The choice shape
* The ability to create transitions between substates in a composite state to states outsite of a state
* The ability to set the rendering direction for a composite state that is isoliated as in without transitions in/out of it.

The default renderer used when using the diagram keyword has been `stateDiagram`. By configuration it has been possible to select which render to use when the diagram starts with `stateDiagram`and the defualt value has been the initial renderer.

This should be changed and the default render should be the new improved one.

**After this change both diagrams starting with `stateDiagram` and `stateDiagram-v2` will use the default renderer**. It will be possible to configure Mermaid to keep the original renderer by the site integrator.

1. Open the online mermaid editor at https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/
2. Enter the code:  
```mermaid
graph
    my_child --> my_parent
```
4. The diagram fails to render...
5. Console output displays:
```
Parse error on line 2:
...    my_child --> my_parent
----------------------^
Expecting 'SEMI', 'NEWLINE', 'SPACE', 'EOF', 'SQS', 'AMP', 'STYLE_SEPARATOR', 'PS', '(-', 'STADIUMSTART', 'SUBROUTINESTART', 'CYLINDERSTART', 'DIAMOND_START', 'TAGEND', 'TRAPSTART', 'INVTRAPSTART', 'START_LINK', 'LINK', 'DOWN', 'NUM', 'COMMA', 'ALPHA', 'COLON', 'MINUS', 'BRKT', 'DOT', 'PUNCTUATION', 'UNICODE_TEXT', 'PLUS', 'EQUALS', 'MULT', 'UNDERSCORE', got 'LINK_TARGET'
```

Notice that any node name ending with "_parent" will fail to render.

**Expected behavior**
It was expected that a graph with the two nodes "my_child" and "my_parent" was rendered.
![mermaid-expected](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/83271564/122193513-d7723580-ce94-11eb-93be-43477c14a5f2.png)

**Additional context**
An obvious workaround is to not create nodes that end with "_parent". For example:

```mermaid
graph

```

Notice that the display name for the "my_parent" node must be in quotes.

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I use Mermaid entity relationship diagrams to model my relational database. Right now the diagram supports only two columns: one for the datatype and another for the field name. However, I would often need to include more information: for instance constraints such as `PK`, `U` `N` for primary key, unique and nullable, respectively. In some cases it would also be good to include a free-form comment as a separate column.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Given an example diagram

```
erDiagram
    CreativeWork {
      TEXT name 
      TEXT description
      TEXT reference
    }
```

I would like the following syntax to be permitted:

```
erDiagram
    CreativeWork {
      TEXT name PK
      TEXT description
      TEXT reference N
    }
```
So I would like to remove the constraint than there can be only two columns on a diagram. Instead a new column could start whenever a space character is detected. If some rows have fewer columns (like `TEXT description` having only two columns whereas other rows have three), the missing columns in the end could simply be considered to be empty.

If I want to mark an empty column which would not be the last one in the row, I could use an empty string. For instance, if I want the different constraint markers to be in their respective columns, the following syntax could be used:
```
erDiagram
    CreativeWork {
      TEXT name PK
      TEXT description
      TEXT reference "" N
    }
```
Now the `N` marker has been shifted to the next column and no longer shares the same column with the `PK` marker.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Right now as only two columns can be used, I attache the additional info to one of the columns using underscores as separators:
```
erDiagram
    CreativeWork {
      TEXT name_PK
      TEXT description
      TEXT reference_N
    }
```
This is not very readable nor good-looking, but it is the best way I have discovered using the current feature set.

**Describe the bug**

When classes are specified to have a link, their font style becomes regular i.o. bold.

When some classes have a link and some other classes do not, the overall class diagram looks strange because some classes have bold font style while others have regular font style.

Readers of the Mermaid diagram may interpret the fact that some classes have bold font style as signifying that these classes are more important or are otherwise significantly different from classes that have regular font style.  But this is not the case, the only difference is that some classes have links.  (And the fact that a class has a link does not decrease its importance for the overall visualizations.)

**To Reproduce**

Steps to reproduce the behavior:

1. Visualize the following Mermaid string.  Notice that the two class have a different font style.

```mermaid
classDiagram
  class Person
  class Monkey
  link Monkey "https://aap.nl" "tooltip"
```

**Expected behavior**

I expect classes without a link to not look "more important" or "more visible" than classes with a link.

Specifically, I expect all classes to have bold font style, regardless of whether they have a link or not.

If the fact that a class has a link must somehow be visually communicated, then there are other ways of doing so that are more common and more appropriate than changing the font style.  For example, classes with a link could have bold font style and be underlined, or they could have a link icon displayed next to their bold name.  (Both approaches are common in web browsers.)

**Screenshots**

Readers of the following diagram interpret "Person" to be somehow more important than "Monkey", but this is not necessarily the intent of the creator of the diagram.  The only difference is that the monkey class can be clicked since a link has been specified for it.

body: # XSS vulnerability ‚Äã ### Vulnerability description ‚Äã In version 8.6.0, Mermaid added a support of directives to add more control over styles(themes) applied to the diagrams. ‚Äã Syntax for declaring the directive is `%%{init: {}}%%` ‚Äã Directives can be used to overwrite default theme properties like fontFamily or fontSize to the graph. ‚Äã Behind the scenes, library takes JSON_OBJECT from directive and merges it with config object. Later that config is used to generate new CSS rules: ``` let userStyles = ''; // user provided theme CSS if (cnf.themeCSS !== undefined) { userStyles += `\n${cnf.themeCSS}`; } // user provided theme CSS if (cnf.fontFamily !== undefined) { userStyles += `\n:root { --mermaid-font-family: ${cnf.fontFamily}}`; } // user provided theme CSS if (cnf.altFontFamily !== undefined) { userStyles += `\n:root { --mermaid-alt-font-family: ${cnf.altFontFamily}}`; } ``` ‚Äã Problem is that there is no sanitization of user-supplied values, which are added to style tag via innerHTML method afterwards: ``` const stylis = new Stylis(); const rules = stylis(`#${id}`, getStyles(graphType, userStyles, cnf.themeVariables)); ‚Äã const style1 = document.createElement('style'); style1.innerHTML = rules; svg.insertBefore(style1, firstChild); ``` ‚Äã This leads to Cross-Site Scripting attack via following directive: ``` %%{init: { 'fontFamily': '\">'} }%% ``` ‚Äã ‚Äã ### Steps to reproduce ‚Äã Create mermaid diagram with following payload: ``` %%{init: { 'fontFamily': '\">'} }%% sequenceDiagram Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice ``` ‚Äã Or visit following PoC: https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/#/edit/eyJjb2RlIjoiJSV7aW5pdDogeyAnZm9udEZhbWlseSc6ICdcXFwiPjwvc3R5bGU-PGltZyBzcmM9eCBvbmVycm9yPWFsZXJ0KGRvY3VtZW50LmNvb2tpZSk-J30gfSUlXG5zZXF1ZW5jZURpYWdyYW1cbkFsaWNlLT4-Qm9iOiBIaSBCb2JcbkJvYi0-PkFsaWNlOiBIaSBBbGljZSIsIm1lcm1haWQiOnsidGhlbWUiOiJkZWZhdWx0In0sInVwZGF0ZUVkaXRvciI6ZmFsc2V9 ‚Äã ‚Äã ‚Äã # Prototype pollution vulnerability ‚Äã ### Vulnerability description ‚Äã In version 8.6.0, Mermaid added a support of directives to add more control over styles(themes) applied to the diagrams. ‚Äã Syntax for declaring the directive is %%{init: {}}%% ‚Äã The issue is that directive JSON_OBJECT is lacking proper sanitization before merging with default config which means we can specify `__proto__` attribute to overwrite Object prototype. ‚Äã For example, if we use following payload, it will add attribute `polluted` to every new object in the application: ``` %%{init: { '__proto__': {'polluted': 'asdf'}} }%% sequenceDiagram Alice->>Bob: Hi Bob Bob->>Alice: Hi Alice ``` ‚Äã ‚Äã This can break the app leading to client-side DOS or can be used to achieve XSS. In some rare cases it can even lead to Remote Code Execution. ‚Äã ### Steps to reproduce Open https://mermaid-js.github.io/mermaid-live-editor/#/edit/eyJjb2RlIjoiJSV7aW5pdDogeyAnX19wcm90b19fJzogeydwb2xsdXRlZCc6ICdhc2RmJ319IH0lJVxuc2VxdWVuY2VEaWFncmFtXG5BbGljZS0-PkJvYjogSGkgQm9iXG5Cb2ItPj5BbGljZTogSGkgQWxpY2VcbiIsIm1lcm1haWQiOnt9LCJ1cGRhdGVFZGl0b3IiOmZhbHNlfQ Then open developer console in the browser and create a new object: ``` a={} a.polluted ``` You will see that newly created object already has `polluted` value. ‚Äã ### Resources You can learn more about this type of vulnerability here: https://portswigger.net/daily-swig/prototype-pollution-the-dangerous-and-underrated-vulnerability-impacting-javascript-applications

**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

I am curious if there is a way to generate a [Data Flow Diagram](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-flow_diagram) using Mermaid (see example screenshot below).

Data Flow Diagrams are common in software Threat Modelling, especially the [STRIDE](https://github.com/AzureArchitecture/threat-model-templates) threat model methodology.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

A a flow `graph` or `stateDiagram` are very similar in concept. In fact, if there is a way to use custom shapes and denote the type of node, then it may very well be possible to achieve this today.

For example, the following Mermaid code would generate the screenshot below:

```
graph
    DataStore[|Database|] -->|input| Process((System)) -->|output| Entity[Customer]
```

Where:

- A node surrounded by `[| |]` denotes a Data Store
- A node surrounded by `(( ))` denotes a Process or Function
- A node surrounded by `[ ]` denotes an External Entity
- Arrows, `-->|label|` denotes a Data Flow labeled as `label`

Besides a few shapes that are missing (e.g. Data Store represented by horizontal parallel lines), all shapes would also need to be available in solid lines and dashed/dotted lines, which denotes being out-of-scope.

**Additional context**

Simple Data Flow Diagram:

![data flow diagram example](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Data-flow-diagram-example.svg/956px-Data-flow-diagram-example.svg.png)

Please describe.** When I'm trying to draw ERD diagrams for a course, using the symbols described in the [Fundamentals of Database System](https://www.amazon.ca/Fundamentals-Database-Systems-Ramez-Elmasri/dp/0133970779). The elements are different from the ERD diagram in mermaid.js, so I revert to using the flowchart. However, I need an underlined node to denote a primary key, but mermaid.js doesn't support underlined nodes **Describe the solution you'd like** Allow underlined nodes **Describe alternatives you've considered** 1. I tried added `` tags. Here's what happened: ``` graph TD User[User] User --> ID(ID/u>) User --> Email(Email) User --> Password(Password) ``` 2. I've also tried adding styles, as per https://github.com/mermaidjs/mermaidjs.github.io/issues/8 ``` graph TD User[User] User --> ID(ID) User --> Email(Email) User --> Password(Password) style ID text-decoration: underline ``` The result is the same as the previous image.

title: Flowchart shapes too small for text in Chromium browsers

body:
**Describe the bug**
If you try to escape class annotations outside of class definition, the diagram fails to render. Take a look at the examples below.

Works fine:
```
classDiagram
     class Klass3 {
       #lt;#lt;interface#gt;#gt;
       +String name
     }
```

Doesn't work:
```
classDiagram
     class Klass3 {
       +String name
     }

     #lt;#lt;interface#gt;#gt; Klass3
```

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open mermaid live editor and type attached code.
2. See error

**Expected behavior**
Both cases should produce the same result.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: OSX
 - Browser: chrome
 - Version 88.0.4324.150 (Official Build) (x86_64)
 - Mermaid version of live editor: 8.8.4

title: Click interactions with hash href returns about:blank instead of a hash link as the href

body:
The syntax doesn't allow specifying nested generic types for the members in a class diagram
**Required output example:**
```
vector<unique_ptr<int>> member
```

The use of `~` for marking both the start and end of generic type results in wrong output with nested generics:

**Input:**
```
vector~unique_ptr~int~~ member
```

**Current output:**
```
vector<unique_ptr>int<> member
```

The solution would be to add proper support for the same with 2 characters (to denote begin and end).

body:
It would be a great idea to support the visualization of labeled node graphs, often used in Visual Scripting.
For example:

![Godot Visual Scripting](https://docs.godotengine.org/en/stable/_images/visual_script1.png)

Syntax could be similiar to the class diagram
```Mermaid
node_one[Node One] {
    < label_symbol_type input_one: "Number"
    < label_symbol_type input_two: "Other Number"
    > label_symbol_type output: "Result"
}

node_one[Node Two] {
    < label_symbol_type input_one: "Number"
    < label_symbol_type input_two: "Other Number"
    > label_symbol_type output: "Result"
}

node_one(output) --> node_two(input_one)
node_one(output) --> node_two(input_two)
```

## Node
`node_one[Node Two]`
Node id and its name.

## Label
`< label_symbol_type input_one: "Number"`
- `<` input label
- `>` output label
The symbol type marks different input/ output symbol for example a circle, triangle, etc. as seen in the image too.

Then the label id with the name.

Additionally would be nice to have an option to change the color of the label symbol.

## Connections
`node_one(output) --> node_two(input_one)`
Node id with the label connects with the known line types to another label.

body:
I would like to be able to manually specify multiple tasks to appear on the same line, to save vertical space for distinct yet related tasks.  Essentially be able to add a new keyword to indicate which line to use.  The user would be responsible for object location clashes (though bonus points if you can specify that the text should be to the left of the object instead of right).

An ideal diagram description might look something like the one below.  The result would be all five tasks appearing on the same line.

```
gantt
    title Example
    Requirements  :a1, 2021-01-11, 4w
    Design  :a2, after a1, sameline a1, 4w
    Development  :a3, after a2, sameline a1, 4w
    Test  :a4, after a3, sameline a1, 4w
    Demo  :crit, a5, after a4, sameline a1, 1d
```

This is perhaps somewhat related to the second item of #1708. I believe it should be added to ganttDb.js's addtask function (and the parser).

I would be willing to sponsor this feature, nearterm.
